Regarding scholarship on Loki, scholar Gabriel Turville-Petre comments (1964) that "more ink has been spilled on Loki than on any other figure in Norse myth This, in itself, is enough to show how little scholars agree, and how far we are from understanding him." [61]


Origin
Loki's origins and role in Norse mythology have been much debated by scholars In 1835, Jacob Grimm was first to produce a major theory about Loki, in which he advanced the notion of Loki as a "god of fire" In 1889, Sophus Bugge theorized Loki to be variant of Lucifer of Christianity, an element of Bugge's larger effort to find a basis of Christianity in Norse mythology After World War II, four scholarly theories dominated The first of the four theories is that of Folke Ström, who in 1956 concluded that Loki is a hypostasis of the god Odin In 1959, Jan de Vries theorized that Loki is a typical example of a trickster figure In 1961, by way of excluding all non-Scandinavian mythological parallels in her analysis, Anna Birgitta Rooth concluded that Loki was originally a spider Anne Holtsmark, writing in 1962, concluded that no conclusion could be made about Loki [62]

A popular theory proposed by a variety of scholars is that Lóðurr is "a third name of Loki/Loptr" The main argument for this is that the gods Odin, Hœnir and Loki occur as a trio in Haustlöng, in the prose prologue to Reginsmál and also in the Loka Táttur a Faroese ballad, an example of Norse deities appearing in later folklore The Odin-kenning "Lóðurr's friend" furthermore appears to parallel the kenning "Loptr's friend" and Loki is similarly referred to as "Hœnir's friend" in Haustlöng, strengthening the trio connection While many scholars agree with this identification, it is not universally accepted One argument against it is that Loki appears as a malevolent being later in Völuspá, seemingly conflicting with the image of Lóðurr as a "mighty and loving" figure Many scholars, including Jan de Vries and Georges Dumézil, have also identified Lóðurr as being the same deity as Loki Scholar Haukur Þorgeirsson suggests that Loki and Lóðurr were different names for the same deity based on conclusion based on the Prose Edda, as Snorri does not mention Lóðurr Since the contents of the Poetic Edda are assumed to have been forgotten around 1400 when the rímur was written, Haukur argues for a traditional identification Þorgeirsson also points to Þrymlur where the same identification is made with Loki and Lóðurr Haukur says that unless the possible but unlikely idea that the 14th- and 15th-century poets possessed written sources unknown to us is true, the idea must have come from either an unlikely amount of sources from where the poets could have drawn a similar conclusion that Loki and Lóðurr are identical (like some recent scholars) or that remnants of an oral tradition remained Haukur concludes that if Lóðurr was historically considered an independent deity from Loki, then a discussion of when and why he became identified with Loki is appropriate [63]


Binding
The scholar John Lindow highlights the recurring pattern of the bound monster in Norse mythology as being particularly associated to Loki Loki and his three children by Angrboda were all bound in some way, and were all destined to break free at Ragnarok to wreak havoc on the world He suggests a borrowed element from the traditions of the Caucasus region, and identifies a mythological parallel with the "Christian legend of the bound Antichrist awaiting the Last Judgment" [64]

Korean dramas, also known as K-dramas, are a genre of television dramas that originated in South Korea. They are known for their engaging storylines, memorable characters, and cultural significance. This list provides an extensive catalog of notable Korean dramas, categorized alphabetically.

title: Jujutsu_Kaisen
content:
Synopsis
In Jujutsu Kaisen, all living beings emanate energy called Cursed Energy (呪力, Juryoku), which arises from negative emotions that naturally flow throughout the body Ordinary people cannot control this flow in their bodies As a result, they continually lose Cursed Energy, resulting in the birth of Curses (呪い, Noroi), a race of spiritual beings whose primary desire is to bring harm to humanity These Curses are shown as gruesome monsters: onryō (vengeful spirit), yūrei (ghosts), and yōkai.


Setting
In Jujutsu Kaisen, all living beings emanate energy called Cursed Energy (呪力, Juryoku), which arises from negative emotions that naturally flow throughout the body Ordinary people cannot control this flow in their bodies As a result, they continually lose Cursed Energy, resulting in the birth of Curses (呪い, Noroi), a race of spiritual beings whose primary desire is to bring harm to humanity These Curses are shown as gruesome monsters: onryō (vengeful spirit), yūrei (ghosts), and yōkai.


Plot
Yuji Itadori is a high school student with unnatural physical strength One day at school, his friends attract Curses by unsealing a rotten finger talisman Yuji swallows the finger to protect Jujutsu Sorcerer student Megumi Fushiguro—on site to retrieve the finger—unwittingly becoming host to the powerful ancient sorcerer Ryomen Sukuna All sorcerers must exorcise Sukuna, and Yuji by extension However, noticing his capability to retain control over his body, Satoru Gojo—Megumi's teacher and the strongest sorcerer in the modern Jujutsu world—brings him to the Tokyo Prefectural Jujutsu High School to train him Gojo has Yuji's execution postponed until he consumes all twenty of Sukuna's fingers, so the Curse can be eliminated permanently with his death.


Production
Manga author Gege Akutami first published Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School, a four-chapter series that ran in Jump Giga from April 28 to July 28, 2017 [4] [5] The series would later serve as a prologue to Jujutsu Kaisen and was retitled as Jujutsu Kaisen 0 [6] According to Hiroyuki Nakano, the chief editor of Weekly Shōnen Jump, Jujutsu Kaisen received unanimous approval in the serialization committee [7] It debuted in Weekly Shōnen Jump on March 5, 2018 [8]


Development
Manga author Gege Akutami first published Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School, a four-chapter series that ran in Jump Giga from April 28 to July 28, 2017 [4] [5] The series would later serve as a prologue to Jujutsu Kaisen and was retitled as Jujutsu Kaisen 0 [6] According to Hiroyuki Nakano, the chief editor of Weekly Shōnen Jump, Jujutsu Kaisen received unanimous approval in the serialization committee [7] It debuted in Weekly Shōnen Jump on March 5, 2018 [8]


Conclusion
In October 2020, Akutami stated that the story's ending and main stages were planned, but that the path between the two remained "fairly free." [9] In February 2021, Akutami stated that the series would probably be finished within two years, declaring, however, no confidence in that statement Akutami knew how the story for Megumi Fushiguro would end, but not for Sukuna [15] On June 9, 2021, it was announced that the manga would enter on hiatus due to the author's health issues; [16] [17] it resumed publication on August 2 of the same year [18] [19] In December 2022, Akutami hinted that the manga would end within a year, stating during the Jump Festa '23 event: "If you accompany me for up to one more year (probably), I will be very happy." [20] In December 2023, at the Jump Festa '24 event, Akutami stated in a handwritten comment that it would probably be the last Jump Festa in which the series would continue in serialization, hinting that it would end within 2024; [21] the series concluded on September 30 of said year [22] [23]


Media
Written and illustrated by Gege Akutami, Jujutsu Kaisen was serialized in Shueisha's Weekly Shōnen Jump magazine from March 5, 2018, [2] [8] to September 30, 2024 [23] [24] Its chapters are collected and published by Shueisha into individual tankōbon volumes The first volume was published on July 4, 2018 [25] As of October 4, 2024, 28 volumes have been released [26] The 30th and final volume is set to be released on December 25, 2024 [24]


Manga
Written and illustrated by Gege Akutami, Jujutsu Kaisen was serialized in Shueisha's Weekly Shōnen Jump magazine from March 5, 2018, [2] [8] to September 30, 2024 [23] [24] Its chapters are collected and published by Shueisha into individual tankōbon volumes The first volume was published on July 4, 2018 [25] As of October 4, 2024, 28 volumes have been released [26] The 30th and final volume is set to be released on December 25, 2024 [24]


Novels
Jujutsu Kaisen: Iku Natsu to Kaeru Aki and Jujutsu Kaisen: Yoake no Ibara Michi were among the best-selling novel series in the first half of 2021 (period between November 2020 and May 2021), with 235,170 and 206,059 copies sold, respectively, [147] and both novels were the best-selling-novel volumes in the first half of 2021 [148] Both novels were the best-selling novels of 2021, collectively selling a total of 487,434 copies [149]


Anime
A 24-episode anime television series adaptation produced by MAPPA was broadcast on MBS's Super Animeism block and TBS from October 3, 2020, to March 27, 2021 [38] [39] [40] [b]


Video games
In June 2021, a free-to-play role-playing mobile game, titled Jujutsu Kaisen: Phantom Parade, developed by Sumzap, was announced [46] The game was set to be released in 2022; [47] however, it was delayed to November 21, 2023 [48] The game was released internationally on November 7, 2024 [49] [50] [51]


Stage plays
A stage play adaptation of the manga was announced at the Jump Festa '22 event in December 2021 [63] It ran at The Galaxy Theatre in Tokyo's Tennōzu from July 15–31, and scheduled to run at the Mielparque Hall Osaka from August 4–14, 2022; [64] however, due to an actor's injury, the stage play in Osaka was delayed and started on August 7 [65] [66] The play was directed by Kensaku Kobayashi and written by Kōhei Kiyasu The cast included Ryūji Satō as Yuji Itadori, Kazuaki Yasue as Megumi Fushiguro, Erika Toyohara as Nobara Kugisaki, Sara Takatsuki as Maki Zen'in, Fūma Sadamoto as Toge Inumaki, and Takeshi Terayama as Panda [64]


Other media
A fanbook, titled Jujutsu Kaisen: The Official Character Guide (呪術廻戦 公式ファンブック, Jujutsu Kaisen Kōshiki Fanbukku, lit. 'Jujutsu Kaisen Official Fanbook'), was published by Shueisha on March 4, 2021 It features exclusive information about the series, character profiles, author commentaries, an interview and a special dialogue between Akutami and Bleach author Tite Kubo [69] In June 2023, Viz Media announced its acquisition, and released it on April 23, 2024 [70] [71]


Reception
Jujutsu Kaisen ranked first on the "Nationwide Bookstore Employees' Recommended Comics" by the Honya Club website in 2019 [78] [79] The series ranked 31st on the 2020 "Book of the Year" list by Da Vinci magazine; [80] it ranked fourth on the 2021 list; [81] sixth on the 2022 list; [82] and fourteenth on the 2023 list [83] On TV Asahi's Manga Sōsenkyo 2021 poll, in which 150,000 people voted for their top 100 manga series, Jujutsu Kaisen ranked nineteenth [84] [85] On a 2021 survey conducted by Line Research asking Japanese high school students what manga series they are currently into, Jujutsu Kaisen topped the rankings for both girls and boys [86]


Popularity
Jujutsu Kaisen ranked first on the "Nationwide Bookstore Employees' Recommended Comics" by the Honya Club website in 2019 [78] [79] The series ranked 31st on the 2020 "Book of the Year" list by Da Vinci magazine; [80] it ranked fourth on the 2021 list; [81] sixth on the 2022 list; [82] and fourteenth on the 2023 list [83] On TV Asahi's Manga Sōsenkyo 2021 poll, in which 150,000 people voted for their top 100 manga series, Jujutsu Kaisen ranked nineteenth [84] [85] On a 2021 survey conducted by Line Research asking Japanese high school students what manga series they are currently into, Jujutsu Kaisen topped the rankings for both girls and boys [86]


Sales
The Jujutsu Kaisen manga had 600,000 copies in circulation by December 2018; [89] 770,000 copies in circulation by February 1, 2019; [90] 1.1 million copies in circulation by February 2019; [91] 2 million copies in circulation by June 2019; [92] 2.5 million copies in circulation by November 2019; [93] 4.5 million copies in circulation by May 2020; [94] 6.8 million copies in circulation by September 2020; [95] and over 10 million copies in circulation by October 2020, [c] having grown 400% in one year, and about 230% in a half year [96] [97] By December 2020, the series had 15 million copies in circulation [c] [98] By January 13, 2021, the series had over 20 million copies in circulation, [c] [99] [100] and increased to 25 million copies in circulation by January 26 [101] [102] By February 2021, the manga had over 30 million copies in circulation [c] [103] [104] By the start of March 2021, the series had over 36 million copies in circulation, [c] [105] and by the end of the month, the manga recorded over 40 million copies in circulation [106] By April 2021, the manga had over 45 million copies in circulation [c] [107] [108] By May 2021, the manga had over 50 million copies in circulation [c] [109] [110] By October 2021, the manga had over 55 million copies in circulation [c] [111] [112] By December 2021, the manga had over 60 million copies in circulation [c] [113] By April 2022, the manga had over 65 million copies in circulation [c] [114] By August 2022, the manga had over 70 million copies in circulation [c] [115] By July 2023, the manga had over 80 million copies in circulation [c] [116] By January 2024, the manga had over 90 million copies in circulation [c] [117] By September 2024, the manga had over 100 million copies in circulation [c] [118]


Critical reception
Leroy Douresseaux of Comic Book Bin gave the first volume a score of 8.5/10 Douresseaux praised the series for its characters, plots, settings, and internal mythology, and described it as a "combination battle manga and horror comic book" [137] Shawn Hacaga of The Fandom Post, in his review of the first volume, compared the series to early Bleach and praised it for its world, lore, characters and artwork, concluding that it is a "solid first volume" [138] Hannah Collins of CBR found parallels between Yuji and Sukuna and Marvel Comics characters Eddie Brock and Venom She also noted similarities to Bleach, Blue Exorcist and Tokyo Ghoul Collins commended the manga and, regarding its then recently announced anime adaptation, concluded that Jujutsu Kaisen is a "darkly enjoyable action series that's sure to be one to watch out for in 2020" [139] Rebecca Silverman of Anime News Network ranked the first volume as a C Silverman praised the series' use of Japanese folklore and yōkai elements, comparing this and Akutami's art style to Shigeru Mizuki's GeGeGe no Kitarō, but criticized the story for being "very generic" She concluded, "It has the potential to be more as Akutami gets more comfortable with the serialization process and figures out precisely where the story is going, so it may be worth a second book to be certain But as of this one, it's just okay, making it the kind of series that gets damned with faint praise" [140] Azusa Takahashi of Real Sound praised its storytelling, setting and "surprising" story development, also noting similarities to other works like Bleach, Ushio & Tora or Neon Genesis Evangelion, stating, however, that the series is not only a homage to popular works centered on the battle development, but that it has a "clever composition that sublimates into originality" [141]


Accolades
Jujutsu Kaisen was sixth on the fifth Next Manga Awards in the Print category in 2018 [142] It won the third annual Tsutaya Comic Award in 2019 [143] In 2019, the manga was nominated for the 65th Shogakukan Manga Award in the shōnen category [144] Jujutsu Kaisen won the Mandō Kobayashi Manga Grand Prix 2020, created by comedian and manga enthusiast Kendo Kobayashi, in which each year's winner is decided based on his personal taste [145] The manga was nominated for the 25th annual Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize in 2021 [146]


Novels
Jujutsu Kaisen: Iku Natsu to Kaeru Aki and Jujutsu Kaisen: Yoake no Ibara Michi were among the best-selling novel series in the first half of 2021 (period between November 2020 and May 2021), with 235,170 and 206,059 copies sold, respectively, [147] and both novels were the best-selling-novel volumes in the first half of 2021 [148] Both novels were the best-selling novels of 2021, collectively selling a total of 487,434 copies [149]


Notes


References

article:
**Introduction**

Jujutsu Kaisen is a Japanese manga series written and illustrated by Gege Akutami. The series has gained immense popularity worldwide for its unique blend of action, horror, and fantasy elements. It has been serialized in Shueisha's Weekly Shōnen Jump magazine since March 2018 and has been adapted into an anime television series, which was broadcast from October 2020 to March 2021.

**Synopsis**

In Jujutsu Kaisen, all living beings emanate energy called Cursed Energy (呪力, Juryoku), which arises from negative emotions that naturally flow throughout the body. Ordinary people cannot control this flow in their bodies, resulting in the birth of Curses (呪い, Noroi), a race of spiritual beings whose primary desire is to bring harm to humanity. These Curses are shown as gruesome monsters: onryō (vengeful spirit), yūrei (ghosts), and yōkai.

**Setting**

The story takes place in a world where Jujutsu Sorcerers, individuals with the ability to manipulate Cursed Energy, fight against Curses to protect humanity. The Jujutsu Sorcerers are trained at the Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School, where they learn various techniques to combat Curses.

**Plot**

The story follows Yuji Itadori, a high school student with unnatural physical strength. One day at school, his friends attract Curses by unsealing a rotten finger talisman. Yuji swallows the finger to protect Jujutsu Sorcerer student Megumi Fushiguro—on site to retrieve the finger. Unwittingly, Yuji becomes host to the powerful ancient sorcerer Ryomen Sukuna. All sorcerers must exorcise Sukuna, and Yuji by extension. However, noticing his capability to retain control over his body, Satoru Gojo—Megumi's teacher and the strongest sorcerer in the modern Jujutsu world—brings him to the Tokyo Prefectural Jujutsu High School to train him. Gojo has Yuji's execution postponed until he consumes all twenty of Sukuna's fingers, so the Curse can be eliminated permanently with his death.

**Production**

Manga author Gege Akutami first published Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School, a four-chapter series that ran in Jump Giga from April 28 to July 28, 2017. The series would later serve as a prologue to Jujutsu Kaisen and was retitled as Jujutsu Kaisen 0. According to Hiroyuki Nakano, the chief editor of Weekly Shōnen Jump, Jujutsu Kaisen received unanimous approval in the serialization committee. It debuted in Weekly Shōnen Jump on March 5, 2018.

**Development**

Gege Akutami's unique art style and storytelling have been praised for their complexity and depth. The series has been compared to other works in the shōnen genre, such as Bleach and Naruto, for its blend of action, humor, and drama. However, Jujutsu Kaisen has also been noted for its darker and more mature themes, which set it apart from other shōnen series.

**Conclusion**

In October 2020, Akutami stated that the story's ending and main stages were planned, but that the path between the two remained "fairly free." In February 2021, Akutami stated that the series would probably be finished within two years, declaring, however, no confidence in that statement. On June 9, 2021, it was announced that the manga would enter on hiatus due to the author's health issues; however, it resumed publication on August 2 of the same year. In December 2022, Akutami hinted that the manga would end within a year, stating during the Jump Festa '23 event: "If you accompany me for up to one more year (probably), I will be very happy." In December 2023, at the Jump Festa '24 event, Akutami stated in a handwritten comment that it would probably be the last Jump Festa in which the series would continue in serialization, hinting that it would end within 2024; the series concluded on September 30 of said year.

**Media**

Written and illustrated by Gege Akutami, Jujutsu Kaisen was serialized in Shueisha's Weekly Shōnen Jump magazine from March 5, 2018, to September 30, 2024. Its chapters are collected and published by Shueisha into individual tankōbon volumes. The first volume was published on July 4, 2018. As of October 4, 2024, 28 volumes have been released. The 30th and final volume is set to be released on December 25, 2024.

**Manga**

Jujutsu Kaisen is a manga series that has been serialized in Weekly Shōnen Jump since March 2018. It has been adapted into an anime television series, which was broadcast from October 2020 to March 2021. The series has also been released in various countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, and Australia.

**Novels**

Jujutsu Kaisen: Iku Natsu to Kaeru Aki and Jujutsu Kaisen: Yoake no Ibara Michi were among the best-selling novel series in the first half of 2021, with 235,170 and 206,059 copies sold, respectively. Both novels were the best-selling-novel volumes in the first half of 2021. Both novels were the best-selling novels of 2021, collectively selling a total of 487,434 copies.

**Anime**

A 24-episode anime television series adaptation of Jujutsu Kaisen was produced by MAPPA and broadcast on MBS's Super Animeism block and TBS from October 3, 2020, to March 27, 2021.

**Video Games**

In June 2021, a free-to-play role-playing mobile game, titled Jujutsu Kaisen: Phantom Parade, developed by Sumzap, was announced. The game was set to be released in 2022; however, it was delayed to November 21, 2023. The game was released internationally on November 7, 2024.

**Stage Plays**

A stage play adaptation of the manga was announced at the Jump Festa '22 event in December 2021. It ran at The Galaxy Theatre in Tokyo's Tennōzu from July 15–31, and scheduled to run at the Mielparque Hall Osaka from August 4–14, 2022; however, due to an actor's injury, the stage play in Osaka was delayed and started on August 7. The play was directed by Kensaku Kobayashi and written by Kōhei Kiyasu. The cast included Ryūji Satō as Yuji Itadori, Kazuaki Yasue as Megumi Fushiguro, Erika Toyohara as Nobara Kugisaki, Sara Takatsuki as Maki Zen'in, Fūma Sadamoto as Toge Inumaki, and Takeshi Terayama as Panda.

**Other Media**

A fanbook, titled Jujutsu Kaisen: The Official Character Guide, was published by Shueisha on March 4, 2021. It features exclusive information about the series, character profiles, author commentaries, an interview, and a special dialogue between Akutami and Bleach author Tite Kubo. In June 2023, Viz Media announced its acquisition, and released it on April 23, 2024.

**Reception**

Jujutsu Kaisen ranked first on the "Nationwide Bookstore Employees' Recommended Comics" by the Honya Club website in 2019. The series ranked 31st on the 2020 "Book of the Year" list by Da Vinci magazine; it ranked fourth on the 2021 list; sixth on the 2022 list; and fourteenth on the 2023 list. On TV Asahi's Manga Sōsenkyo 2021 poll, in which 150,000 people voted for their top 100 manga series, Jujutsu Kaisen ranked nineteenth. On a 2021 survey conducted by Line Research asking Japanese high school students what manga series they are currently into, Jujutsu Kaisen topped the rankings for both girls and boys.

**Sales**

The Jujutsu Kaisen manga had 600,000 copies in circulation by December 2018; 770,000 copies in circulation by February 1, 2019; 1.1 million copies in circulation by February 2019; 2 million copies in circulation by June 2019; 2.5 million copies in circulation by November 2019; 4.5 million copies in circulation by May 2020; 6.8 million copies in circulation by September 2020; and over 10 million copies in circulation by October 2020, having grown 400% in one year, and about 230% in a half year. By December 2020, the series had 15 million copies in circulation. By January 13, 2021, the series had over 20 million copies in circulation. By January 26, the series had over 25 million copies in circulation. By February 2021, the manga had over 30 million copies in circulation. By the start of March 2021, the series had over 36 million copies in circulation. By the end of the month, the manga recorded over 40 million copies in circulation. By April 2021, the manga had over 45 million copies in circulation. By May 2021, the manga had over 50 million copies in circulation. By October 2021, the manga had over 55 million copies in circulation. By December 2021, the manga had over 60 million copies in circulation. By April 2022, the manga had over 65 million copies in circulation. By August 2022, the manga had over 70 million copies in circulation. By July 2023, the manga had over 80 million copies in circulation. By January 2024, the manga had over 90 million copies in circulation. By September 2024, the manga had over 100 million copies in circulation.

**Critical Reception**

Leroy Douresseaux of Comic Book Bin gave the first volume a score of 8.5/10. Douresseaux praised the series for its characters, plots, settings, and internal mythology, and described it as a "combination battle manga and horror comic book." Shawn Hacaga of The Fandom Post, in his review of the first volume, compared the series to early Bleach and praised it for its world, lore, characters, and artwork, concluding that it is a "solid first volume." Hannah Collins of CBR found parallels between Yuji and Sukuna and Marvel Comics characters Eddie Brock and Venom. She also noted similarities to Bleach, Blue Exorcist, and Tokyo Ghoul. Collins commended the manga and, regarding its then recently announced anime adaptation, concluded that Jujutsu Kaisen is a "darkly enjoyable action series that's sure to be one to watch out for in 2020." Rebecca Silverman of Anime News Network ranked the first volume as a C. Silverman praised the series' use of Japanese folklore and yōkai elements, comparing this and Akutami's art style to Shigeru Mizuki's GeGeGe no Kitarō, but criticized the story for being "very generic." She concluded, "It has the potential to be more as Akutami gets more comfortable with the serialization process and figures out precisely where the story is going, so it may be worth a second book to be certain But as of this one, it's just okay, making it the kind of series that gets damned with faint praise." Azusa Takahashi of Real Sound praised its storytelling, setting, and "surprising" story development, also noting similarities to other works like Bleach, Ushio & Tora or Neon Genesis Evangelion, stating, however, that the series is not only a homage to popular works centered on the battle development, but that it has a "clever composition that sublimates into originality."

**Accolades**

Jujutsu Kaisen was sixth on the fifth Next Manga Awards in the Print category in 2018. It won the third annual Tsutaya Comic Award in 2019. In 2019, the manga was nominated for the 65th Shogakukan Manga Award in the shōnen category. Jujutsu Kaisen won the Mandō Kobayashi Manga Grand Prix 2020, created by comedian and manga enthusiast Kendo Kobayashi, in which each year's winner is decided based on his personal taste. The manga was nominated for the 25th annual Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize in 2021.

In October 2020, Akutami stated that the story's ending and main stages were planned, but that the path between the two remained "fairly free." [9] In February 2021, Akutami stated that the series would probably be finished within two years, declaring, however, no confidence in that statement Akutami knew how the story for Megumi Fushiguro would end, but not for Sukuna [15] On June 9, 2021, it was announced that the manga would enter on hiatus due to the author's health issues; [16] [17] it resumed publication on August 2 of the same year [18] [19] In December 2022, Akutami hinted that the manga would end within a year, stating during the Jump Festa '23 event: "If you accompany me for up to one more year (probably), I will be very happy." [20] In December 2023, at the Jump Festa '24 event, Akutami stated in a handwritten comment that it would probably be the last Jump Festa in which the series would continue in serialization, hinting that it would end within 2024; [21] the series concluded on September 30 of said year [22] [23]


Media
Written and illustrated by Gege Akutami, Jujutsu Kaisen was serialized in Shueisha's Weekly Shōnen Jump magazine from March 5, 2018, [2] [8] to September 30, 2024 [23] [24] Its chapters are collected and published by Shueisha into individual tankōbon volumes The first volume was published on July 4, 2018 [25] As of October 4, 2024, 28 volumes have been released [26] The 30th and final volume is set to be released on December 25, 2024 [24]


Manga
Written and illustrated by Gege Akutami, Jujutsu Kaisen was serialized in Shueisha's Weekly Shōnen Jump magazine from March 5, 2018, [2] [8] to September 30, 2024 [23] [24] Its chapters are collected and published by Shueisha into individual tankōbon volumes The first volume was published on July 4, 2018 [25] As of October 4, 2024, 28 volumes have been released [26] The 30th and final volume is set to be released on December 25, 2024 [24]


Novels
Jujutsu Kaisen: Iku Natsu to Kaeru Aki and Jujutsu Kaisen: Yoake no Ibara Michi were among the best-selling novel series in the first half of 2021 (period between November 2020 and May 2021), with 235,170 and 206,059 copies sold, respectively, [147] and both novels were the best-selling-novel volumes in the first half of 2021 [148] Both novels were the best-selling novels of 2021, collectively selling a total of 487,434 copies [149]


Anime
A 24-episode anime television series adaptation produced by MAPPA was broadcast on MBS's Super Animeism block and TBS from October 3, 2020, to March 27, 2021 [38] [39] [40] [b]


Video games
In June 2021, a free-to-play role-playing mobile game, titled Jujutsu Kaisen: Phantom Parade, developed by Sumzap, was announced [46] The game was set to be released in 2022; [47] however, it was delayed to November 21, 2023 [48] The game was released internationally on November 7, 2024 [49] [50] [51]


Stage plays
A stage play adaptation of the manga was announced at the Jump Festa '22 event in December 2021 [63] It ran at The Galaxy Theatre in Tokyo's Tennōzu from July 15–31, and scheduled to run at the Mielparque Hall Osaka from August 4–14, 2022; [64] however, due to an actor's injury, the stage play in Osaka was delayed and started on August 7 [65] [66] The play was directed by Kensaku Kobayashi and written by Kōhei Kiyasu The cast included Ryūji Satō as Yuji Itadori, Kazuaki Yasue as Megumi Fushiguro, Erika Toyohara as Nobara Kugisaki, Sara Takatsuki as Maki Zen'in, Fūma Sadamoto as Toge Inumaki, and Takeshi Terayama as Panda [64]


Other media
A fanbook, titled Jujutsu Kaisen: The Official Character Guide (呪術廻戦 公式ファンブック, Jujutsu Kaisen Kōshiki Fanbukku, lit. 'Jujutsu Kaisen Official Fanbook'), was published by Shueisha on March 4, 2021 It features exclusive information about the series, character profiles, author commentaries, an interview and a special dialogue between Akutami and Bleach author Tite Kubo [69] In June 2023, Viz Media announced its acquisition, and released it on April 23, 2024 [70] [71]


Reception
Jujutsu Kaisen ranked first on the "Nationwide Bookstore Employees' Recommended Comics" by the Honya Club website in 2019 [78] [79] The series ranked 31st on the 2020 "Book of the Year" list by Da Vinci magazine; [80] it ranked fourth on the 2021 list; [81] sixth on the 2022 list; [82] and fourteenth on the 2023 list [83] On TV Asahi's Manga Sōsenkyo 2021 poll, in which 150,000 people voted for their top 100 manga series, Jujutsu Kaisen ranked nineteenth [84] [85] On a 2021 survey conducted by Line Research asking Japanese high school students what manga series they are currently into, Jujutsu Kaisen topped the rankings for both girls and boys [86]


Popularity
Jujutsu Kaisen ranked first on the "Nationwide Bookstore Employees' Recommended Comics" by the Honya Club website in 2019 [78] [79] The series ranked 31st on the 2020 "Book of the Year" list by Da Vinci magazine; [80] it ranked fourth on the 2021 list; [81] sixth on the 2022 list; [82] and fourteenth on the 2023 list [83] On TV Asahi's Manga Sōsenkyo 2021 poll, in which 150,000 people voted for their top 100 manga series, Jujutsu Kaisen ranked nineteenth [84] [85] On a 2021 survey conducted by Line Research asking Japanese high school students what manga series they are currently into, Jujutsu Kaisen topped the rankings for both girls and boys [86]


Sales
The Jujutsu Kaisen manga had 600,000 copies in circulation by December 2018; [89] 770,000 copies in circulation by February 1, 2019; [90] 1.1 million copies in circulation by February 2019; [91] 2 million copies in circulation by June 2019; [92] 2.5 million copies in circulation by November 2019; [93] 4.5 million copies in circulation by May 2020; [94] 6.8 million copies in circulation by September 2020; [95] and over 10 million copies in circulation by October 2020, [c] having grown 400% in one year, and about 230% in a half year [96] [97] By December 2020, the series had 15 million copies in circulation [c] [98] By January 13, 2021, the series had over 20 million copies in circulation, [c] [99] [100] and increased to 25 million copies in circulation by January 26 [101] [102] By February 2021, the manga had over 30 million copies in circulation [c] [103] [104] By the start of March 2021, the series had over 36 million copies in circulation, [c] [105] and by the end of the month, the manga recorded over 40 million copies in circulation [106] By April 2021, the manga had over 45 million copies in circulation [c] [107] [108] By May 2021, the manga had over 50 million copies in circulation [c] [109] [110] By October 2021, the manga had over 55 million copies in circulation [c] [111] [112] By December 2021, the manga had over 60 million copies in circulation [c] [113] By April 2022, the manga had over 65 million copies in circulation [c] [114] By August 2022, the manga had over 70 million copies in circulation [c] [115] By July 2023, the manga had over 80 million copies in circulation [c] [116] By January 2024, the manga had over 90 million copies in circulation [c] [117] By September 2024, the manga had over 100 million copies in circulation [c] [118]


Critical reception
Leroy Douresseaux of Comic Book Bin gave the first volume a score of 8.5/10 Douresseaux praised the series for its characters, plots, settings, and internal mythology, and described it as a "combination battle manga and horror comic book" [137] Shawn Hacaga of The Fandom Post, in his review of the first volume, compared the series to early Bleach and praised it for its world, lore, characters and artwork, concluding that it is a "solid first volume" [138] Hannah Collins of CBR found parallels between Yuji and Sukuna and Marvel Comics characters Eddie Brock and Venom She also noted similarities to Bleach, Blue Exorcist and Tokyo Ghoul Collins commended the manga and, regarding its then recently announced anime adaptation, concluded that Jujutsu Kaisen is a "darkly enjoyable action series that's sure to be one to watch out for in 2020" [139] Rebecca Silverman of Anime News Network ranked the first volume as a C Silverman praised the series' use of Japanese folklore and yōkai elements, comparing this and Akutami's art style to Shigeru Mizuki's GeGeGe no Kitarō, but criticized the story for being "very generic" She concluded, "It has the potential to be more as Akutami gets more comfortable with the serialization process and figures out precisely where the story is going, so it may be worth a second book to be certain But as of this one, it's just okay, making it the kind of series that gets damned with faint praise" [140] Azusa Takahashi of Real Sound praised its storytelling, setting and "surprising" story development, also noting similarities to other works like Bleach, Ushio & Tora or Neon Genesis Evangelion, stating, however, that the series is not only a homage to popular works centered on the battle development, but that it has a "clever composition that sublimates into originality" [141]

Jujutsu Kaisen was sixth on the fifth Next Manga Awards in the Print category in 2018 [142] It won the third annual Tsutaya Comic Award in 2019 [143] In 2019, the manga was nominated for the 65th Shogakukan Manga Award in the shōnen category [144] Jujutsu Kaisen won the Mandō Kobayashi Manga Grand Prix 2020, created by comedian and manga enthusiast Kendo Kobayashi, in which each year's winner is decided based on his personal taste [145] The manga was nominated for the 25th annual Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize in 2021 [146]


Novels
Jujutsu Kaisen: Iku Natsu to Kaeru Aki and Jujutsu Kaisen: Yoake no Ibara Michi were among the best-selling novel series in the first half of 2021 (period between November 2020 and May 2021), with 235,170 and 206,059 copies sold, respectively, [147] and both novels were the best-selling-novel volumes in the first half of 2021 [148] Both novels were the best-selling novels of 2021, collectively selling a total of 487,434 copies [149]

article:
Sage Stallone
================

Sage Stallone was an American actor, film producer, and director. He was the son of actor Sylvester Stallone and his first wife, Sasha Czack. Sage was born in Los Angeles, California, and grew up in a family of actors and entertainers. His life and career were marked by struggles with addiction and personal issues, ultimately leading to his untimely death at the age of 36.

Early Life
----------

Sage Stallone was born on July 5, 1976, in Los Angeles, California. He was the elder son and first child of Sylvia "Sasha" Czack, an American schoolteacher, and Sylvester Stallone, a renowned actor and filmmaker. His brother, Seargeoh "Seth" Stallone, was born in 1977. In 1985, Sylvester Stallone married actress Brigitte Nielsen, and Sage had two half-sisters, Sophia and Sistine, born in 1992 and 1996, respectively. His half-brother, Scarlet Stallone, was born in 2002. Sage's maternal grandmother was Jackie Stallone, an American astrologer and actress.

Sage's early life was marked by his family's involvement in the entertainment industry. His father, Sylvester Stallone, was a well-known actor and writer, and his mother worked as a teacher. Sage's childhood was spent attending movie premieres and watching his father work on film sets. He was raised in a household that valued hard work, discipline, and creative expression.

Career
--------

Sage Stallone began his career in the entertainment industry at a young age. As a child, he made a guest appearance on the television series "Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling," a program that was promoted by his grandmother, Jackie Stallone. In the late 1990s, he began working as a production assistant on several of his father's films, including "Judge Dredd" and "Assassins." Sage's own production company, Balboa Productions, was established in 2000, and he went on to produce several independent films, including "Rock 'n' Roll Hell" and "The Agent."

Sage's own acting career was marked by a series of small roles in films and television shows. He appeared in the 2000 film "Vampires: Los Muertos," a sequel to the 1998 film "Bram Stoker's Dracula." In 2002, he played a supporting role in the television series "Kingdom Hospital," a horror drama series created by Stephen King.

Death
------

On July 13, 2012, Sage Stallone was found dead in his home in Studio City, Los Angeles. He was 36 years old. According to reports, he had not been heard from for four days prior to his death. An autopsy by the Los Angeles coroner determined that Sage died of coronary artery disease caused by atherosclerosis, with no drugs detected other than an over-the-counter pain remedy. At the time of his death, Sage was reportedly engaged.

Sage's funeral was held on July 21 at St. Martin of Tours Catholic Church in Los Angeles. He is interred at Westwood Village Memorial Park Cemetery.

Filmography
------------

* "Gorgeous Ladies of Wrestling" (1989)
* "Vampires: Los Muertos" (2002)
* "Kingdom Hospital" (2002)
* "Rock 'n' Roll Hell" (2005)
* "The Agent" (2007)

title: S._Jaishankar
content:
Early life and education
Jaishankar was born in Delhi, India, to a prominent Indian civil servant Krishnaswamy Subrahmanyam [1] [16] and Sulochana Subrahmanyam [1] He was brought up in a Tamil Hindu family [17] He has a sister, Sudha Subrahmanyam, and two brothers: the historian Sanjay Subrahmanyam and the IAS officer S Vijay Kumar, [18] former Rural Development Secretary of India [19] [20]


Diplomatic career (1979–2018)
After joining the Indian Foreign Service in 1977, Jaishankar served as third secretary and second secretary in the Indian mission to the Soviet Union in Moscow from 1979 to 1981, where he studied Russian He returned to New Delhi, where he worked as a special assistant to the diplomat Gopalaswami Parthasarathy and as undersecretary in the Americas division of India's Ministry of External Affairs, dealing with United States He was part of the team that resolved the dispute over the supply of US nuclear fuel to the Tarapur Power Stations in India [16] From 1985 to 1988 he was the first secretary at the Indian embassy in Washington, D.C [25]


High Commissioner to Singapore
From 2007 to 2009, Jaishankar served as India's High Commissioner to Singapore [40] During his tenure, he helped implement the Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) that expanded the Indian business presence in Singapore, [41] and oversaw a defence arrangement by which Singapore keeps some of its military equipment in India on a permanent basis [42] Jaishankar also promoted the Pravasi Bharatiya Divas, [43] and IIMPact [44] in Singapore.


Ambassador to China
Jaishankar was India's longest-serving ambassador to China, with a four-and-a-half-year term [45] In Beijing, Jaishankar was involved in improving economic, trade and cultural relations between China and India, and in managing the Sino-Indian border dispute [46] [47]


Ambassador to United States
Jaishankar was appointed as India's Ambassador to United States in September 2013 He took charge on 23 December 2013, succeeding Nirupama Rao [45] [57] He arrived in United States amid the Devyani Khobragade incident, and was involved in negotiating the Indian diplomat's departure from United States [58] On 29 January 2014, Jaishankar addressed the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, where he argued that "the grand strategy underwriting  [Indian-American] ties is fundamentally sound" but that ties suffered from a "problem of sentiment" [59] [60]


Foreign Secretary (2015–2018)
Jaishankar was appointed as Foreign Secretary of India on 29 January 2015 The announcement of his appointment was made following a 28 January 2015 meeting of the Appointments Committee of the Cabinet chaired by the Prime Minister, Narendra Modi [2] [3] Jaishankar is credited with building the much talked about "aggressive" foreign policy of the Modi government His tenure extension of one year saw a transformation in the working of the ministry of external affairs [8] [9]
His appointment came three days before the date on which he would ordinarily have retired and meant the unprecedented termination of Sujatha Singh’s two year tenure as Foreign Secretary Singh was offered a sinecure as compensation but preferred to resign from government service Jaishankar is widely criticised by Nepalese analysts for being the "original planner of 2015 Nepal blockade" [64] [65] His tenure expired in January 2018 [66]


Minister of External Affairs (2019–present)
On 31 May 2019, he was appointed to the Office of Minister of External Affairs [67] Jaishankar was sworn in as Cabinet minister on 30 May 2019 [68] On 5 July 2019, he was elected as Member of Parliament from Bharatiya Janata Party to the Rajya Sabha from Gujarat [69] He succeeded Sushma Swaraj who was the External Affairs Minister in Narendra Modi's first government.


Personal life
Jaishankar was married to his first wife Shobha until she succumbed to cancer The two had met while studying at JNU [91] Later, he married Kyoko, who is of Japanese origin [92] whom he met while working in the Indian embassy in Japan They have two sons, Dhruva and Arjun, and a daughter, Medha [93] Jaishankar speaks Russian, English, Tamil, Hindi, conversational Japanese, Chinese and some Hungarian [16]


State honours
The Government of India awarded him Padma Shri, the fourth-highest civilian honour, in 2019 for his contributions to Indian diplomacy and leading role in restructuring India's global conversations [94]


Bibliography


See also


References


External links
article:
**S. Jaishankar**

S. Jaishankar is an Indian diplomat and politician who has served as the Minister of External Affairs of India since 2019. He has had a distinguished career in the Indian Foreign Service, holding various positions, including Ambassador to the United States, China, and Singapore, as well as Foreign Secretary of India. Jaishankar has been credited with playing a key role in shaping India's foreign policy and has been recognized for his contributions to Indian diplomacy.

**Early Life and Education**

S. Jaishankar was born in Delhi, India, to a prominent Indian civil servant, Krishnaswamy Subrahmanyam, and Sulochana Subrahmanyam. He was brought up in a Tamil Hindu family and has a sister, Sudha Subrahmanyam, and two brothers, the historian Sanjay Subrahmanyam and IAS officer S Vijay Kumar. Jaishankar studied Russian language and literature at the Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), where he also met his first wife, Shobha, who succumbed to cancer.

**Diplomatic Career (1979–2018)**

Jaishankar joined the Indian Foreign Service in 1977 and served as third secretary and second secretary in the Indian mission to the Soviet Union in Moscow from 1979 to 1981. During his tenure, he studied Russian and developed a deep understanding of the Soviet Union's politics and economy. After returning to New Delhi, Jaishankar worked as a special assistant to the diplomat Gopalaswami Parthasarathy and as undersecretary in the Americas division of India's Ministry of External Affairs, dealing with United States. He was part of the team that resolved the dispute over the supply of US nuclear fuel to the Tarapur Power Stations in India.

In 1985, Jaishankar was posted to Washington, D.C, where he served as first secretary at the Indian embassy. During his tenure, he played a key role in strengthening Indo-US relations and was involved in negotiating several agreements, including the India-US nuclear cooperation agreement. Jaishankar's tenure in Washington, D.C, laid the foundation for his future roles as Ambassador to the United States and Foreign Secretary of India.

**High Commissioner to Singapore**

From 2007 to 2009, Jaishankar served as India's High Commissioner to Singapore. During his tenure, he helped implement the Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) that expanded the Indian business presence in Singapore. Jaishankar also oversaw a defence arrangement by which Singapore kept some of its military equipment in India on a permanent basis. He promoted the Pravasi Bharatiya Divas and IIMPact in Singapore, initiatives aimed at strengthening ties between the Indian diaspora and the Indian government.

**Ambassador to China**

Jaishankar was India's longest-serving Ambassador to China, serving a four-and-a-half-year term. During his tenure, he was involved in improving economic, trade, and cultural relations between China and India. Jaishankar also managed the Sino-Indian border dispute, which has been a longstanding issue between the two countries.

**Ambassador to United States**

Jaishankar was appointed as India's Ambassador to the United States in September 2013. He took charge on 23 December 2013, succeeding Nirupama Rao. Jaishankar arrived in the United States amid the Devyani Khobragade incident, and was involved in negotiating the Indian diplomat's departure from the United States. On 29 January 2014, Jaishankar addressed the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, where he argued that the grand strategy underwriting Indo-US ties is fundamentally sound, but that ties suffered from a problem of sentiment.

**Foreign Secretary (2015–2018)**

Jaishankar was appointed as Foreign Secretary of India on 29 January 2015. The announcement of his appointment was made following a meeting of the Appointments Committee of the Cabinet chaired by the Prime Minister, Narendra Modi. Jaishankar is credited with building the much-talked-about "aggressive" foreign policy of the Modi government. His tenure extension of one year saw a transformation in the working of the Ministry of External Affairs.

**Minister of External Affairs (2019–present)**

On 31 May 2019, Jaishankar was appointed to the Office of Minister of External Affairs. He was sworn in as Cabinet minister on 30 May 2019. On 5 July 2019, he was elected as Member of Parliament from Bharatiya Janata Party to the Rajya Sabha from Gujarat. Jaishankar succeeded Sushma Swaraj, who was the External Affairs Minister in Narendra Modi's first government.

**Personal Life**

Jaishankar was married to his first wife, Shobha, until she succumbed to cancer. He later married Kyoko, who is of Japanese origin, whom he met while working in the Indian embassy in Japan. Jaishankar has two sons, Dhruva and Arjun, and a daughter, Medha. He speaks Russian, English, Tamil, Hindi, conversational Japanese, Chinese, and some Hungarian.

**State Honours**

The Government of India awarded Jaishankar the Padma Shri, the fourth-highest civilian honour, in 2019 for his contributions to Indian diplomacy and leading role in restructuring India's global conversations.

title: JSON-LD
content:
Design
JSON-LD is designed around the concept of a "context" to provide additional mappings from JSON to an RDF model The context links object properties in a JSON document to concepts in an ontology In order to map the JSON-LD syntax to RDF, JSON-LD allows values to be coerced to a specified type or to be tagged with a language A context can be embedded directly in a JSON-LD document or put into a separate file and referenced from different documents (from traditional JSON documents via an HTTP Link header).


Example

article:
**JSON-LD**

JSON-LD, or JavaScript Object Notation for Linked Data, is a lightweight data interchange format that enables the creation of semantically linked data. It is designed to provide a simple and flexible way to represent data in a format that can be easily understood by both humans and machines.

**Design**

JSON-LD is designed around the concept of a "context" to provide additional mappings from JSON to an RDF model. The context links object properties in a JSON document to concepts in an ontology. In order to map the JSON-LD syntax to RDF, JSON-LD allows values to be coerced to a specified type or to be tagged with a language. A context can be embedded directly in a JSON-LD document or put into a separate file and referenced from different documents (from traditional JSON documents via an HTTP Link header).

The context is used to provide additional information about the properties and types used in the JSON document. This allows the data to be interpreted correctly by systems that understand the ontology. For example, if a JSON document contains a property called "name", the context can specify that this property is a human name, and that it should be interpreted as a string.

**Example**

The following example describes a person, based on the FOAF (friend of a friend) ontology:
```
{
  "@context": "http://www.w3.org/ns/foaf",
  "@id": "http://example.org/person/john",
  "name": "John Doe",
  "homepage": "http://example.org/john",
  "type": ["Person"]
}
```
In this example, the `@context` property specifies that the document is using the FOAF ontology. The `@id` property specifies the IRI that identifies the person. The `name` property is a human name, and the `homepage` property is an IRI that identifies the person's homepage. The `type` property specifies that the person is a `Person`.

First, the two JSON properties `name` and `homepage` and the type `Person` are mapped to concepts in the FOAF vocabulary, and the value of the `homepage` property is specified to be of the type `@id`. In other words, the `homepage` id is specified to be an IRI in the context definition. Based on the RDF model, this allows the person described in the document to be unambiguously identified by an IRI. The use of resolvable IRIs allows RDF documents containing more information to be transcluded, which enables clients to discover new data by simply following those links; this principle is known as 'Follow Your Nose'.

**Use**

The encoding is used by Schema.org, Google Knowledge Graph, and used mostly for search engine optimization activities. It has also been used for applications such as biomedical informatics, and representing provenance information. It is also the basis of Activity Streams, a format for "the exchange of information about potential and completed activities", and is used in ActivityPub, the federated social networking protocol. Additionally, it is used in the context of Internet of Things (IoT), where a Thing Description, which is a JSON-LD document, describes the network facing interfaces of IoT devices.

Schema.org uses JSON-LD to provide structured data about web pages, which can be used by search engines to improve the relevance of search results. Google Knowledge Graph uses JSON-LD to provide additional information about entities, such as people, places, and organizations, that can be used to improve the accuracy of search results.

**See also**

* RDF (Resource Description Framework)
* OWL (Web Ontology Language)
* SPARQL (SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language)
* Linked Data

**References**

* [1] JSON-LD specification
* [2] W3C RDF Working Group
* [3] Schema.org
* [4] Google Knowledge Graph
* [5] FOAF (Friend of a Friend) ontology
* [6] Activity Streams
* [7] ActivityPub
* [8] Internet of Things (IoT)

**External links**

* JSON-LD website
* W3C RDF Working Group
* Schema.org website
* Google Knowledge Graph website
* FOAF (Friend of a Friend) ontology website
* Activity Streams website
* ActivityPub website

Nicholas Scratch

Nicholas Scratch is a fictional supervillain appearing in American comic books published by Marvel Comics. He first appeared in Fantastic Four #185 (August 1977) and was created by writer Len Wein and artist George Pérez.

# Publication History

Nicholas Scratch first appeared in Fantastic Four #185 (August 1977), a comic book published by Marvel Comics. He was created by writer Len Wein and artist George Pérez. Since his debut, Scratch has appeared in various Marvel Comics titles, often as a foe to the Fantastic Four.

# Fictional Character Biography

Nicholas Scratch is the son of Agatha Harkness, a powerful witch who played a significant role in the Marvel Comics universe. Scratch originates from New Salem, Colorado, a secret community of magic users. After Agatha leaves Salem, Scratch becomes a warlock and the father of Salem's Seven with several mothers. He turns Salem's residents against Agatha, but is defeated and banished to the Dark Realm after the Fantastic Four confront him.

Scratch's backstory is deeply connected to Agatha Harkness and the community of New Salem. Agatha, a powerful witch, was a significant figure in the Marvel Comics universe, and her relationship with Scratch played a crucial role in shaping his character. Scratch's transformation into a warlock and his subsequent actions against Agatha and the Fantastic Four are a testament to his complex and multifaceted personality.

# Powers and Abilities

Nicholas Scratch possesses vast indeterminate power through manipulation of the forces of magic. This gives him various magical powers, including teleportation, energy manipulation, dimensional travel, mind control, telepathy, and illusion generation. Scratch also wields the Satan Staff, a mystical power object that focuses his magic.

Scratch's use of magic also allows him to perform various illusions, making it difficult for his opponents to discern reality from fantasy. His telepathic abilities enable him to read the thoughts of others, giving him an advantage in combat and strategic situations. His mind control powers allow him to manipulate the actions of others, making him a master of manipulation and deception.

# In Other Media

Nicholas Scratch has not appeared in any Marvel Comics adaptations, such as movies or television shows. However, his character has been mentioned in various Marvel Comics titles and has played a significant role in the Marvel Comics universe.

Scratch's absence from Marvel Comics adaptations is not surprising, given his relatively minor role in the Marvel Comics universe. However, his character has played a significant role in various Marvel Comics titles, making him a fascinating and complex character in the Marvel Comics universe.

article:
UEFA Euro 1992

The UEFA Euro 1992 was the seventh European Football Championship, held from June 10 to June 12, 1992, in Sweden. The tournament was won by Denmark, who defeated Germany 2-0 in the final.

Bid process

The host country was chosen on December 16, 1988, after a decision made by the UEFA Executive Committee. Sweden was selected over Spain, who had already been chosen to host the EXPO 1992 in Seville and the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona. This decision was made because Spain was unable to accommodate the tournament due to their existing commitments.

Summary

The tournament featured 8 teams, with 7 of them qualifying through a qualification process. Sweden qualified automatically as the host country. The Soviet Union qualified shortly before the break-up of the country, and participated under the banner of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). The CIS team represented 11 former Soviet nations: Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Kyrgyzstan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Moldova, and Tajikistan. Four out of 15 ex-republics did not send their players: Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, while Georgia was not a member of the CIS at the time, but Georgian player Kakhaber Tskhadadze was part of the squad.

Qualification

The qualification process was held from October 1988 to November 1991. Scotland and Sweden made their respective debuts despite having already made many appearances at the World Cup. France qualified for the first Euro in which they were not the hosts, and played after missing the previous tournament.

Qualified teams

The draw for the final tournament took place on January 17, 1992, in Gothenburg. Only two teams were seeded: Sweden (as hosts) and the Netherlands (as holders). The remaining six teams were all unseeded and could be drawn in any group. Months after the draw, Yugoslavia was banned from participating and replaced by Denmark, which had come second in the qualifying group.

Venues

Each national team had to submit a squad of 20 players. The tournament was held in several venues across Sweden, including the Råsunda Stadium in Solna, the Ullevi Stadium in Gothenburg, and the Eyravallen Stadium in Örebro.

Squads

Each national team had to submit a squad of 20 players. The squads were announced before the tournament, with teams able to make late changes due to injuries or other reasons.

Match ball

The official match ball of the tournament was the Adidas Etrusco Unico, which was previously used in the 1990 FIFA World Cup.

Match officials

The teams finishing in the top two positions in each of the two groups progressed to the semi-finals, while the bottom two teams in each group were eliminated from the tournament.

Group stage

The group stage was held from June 10 to June 14, 1992. The teams were divided into two groups of four, with the top two teams in each group advancing to the semi-finals.

Tiebreakers

If two or more teams finished level on points after completion of the group matches, the following tie-breakers were used to determine the final ranking: goal difference, goals scored, and then a drawing of lots.

Group 1

The teams in Group 1 were Denmark, France, Sweden, and England. Denmark topped the group with 7 points, followed by France with 6 points. Sweden and England finished third and fourth with 5 and 1 point respectively.

Group 2

The teams in Group 2 were the Netherlands, Germany, Scotland, and CIS. Germany topped the group with 6 points, followed by the Netherlands with 5 points. Scotland and CIS finished third and fourth with 4 and 2 points respectively.

Knockout stage

The knockout stage was held from June 17 to June 19, 1992. The teams that advanced to the semi-finals were Denmark, France, Germany, and the Netherlands.

Semi-finals

The semi-finals were held on June 17, 1992. Denmark defeated Germany 5-4 in a penalty shootout, after the match ended 0-0 after extra time. France defeated the Netherlands 2-0 in the other semi-final.

Final

The final was held on June 19, 1992, at the Råsunda Stadium in Solna. Denmark defeated Germany 2-0, with goals from Lars Elstrup and Brian Laudrup.

Statistics

There were 32 goals scored in 15 matches, for an average of 2.13 goals per match.

Goalscorers

The top scorers of the tournament were Dennis Bergkamp of the Netherlands with 3 goals, followed by Henrik Larsen of Denmark with 3 goals.

Awards

The official slogan of the contest was "Small is Beautiful", while the official anthem was "More Than a Game", performed by Towe Jaarnek and Peter Jöback.

Marketing

The tournament was marketed extensively, with the official logo and mascot being used to promote the event.

Slogan and theme song

The official slogan of the contest was "Small is Beautiful", while the official anthem was "More Than a Game", performed by Towe Jaarnek and Peter Jöback.

Logo and identity

The tournament used the UEFA plus flag logo, which was the last time it was used before being replaced. The logo and identity of the tournament were designed to reflect the theme of the contest.

Mascot

The official mascot of the competition was a rabbit named Rabbit, who was dressed in a Swedish football jersey.

Sponsorship

The tournament had several sponsors, including Adidas, Carlsberg, and Volvo.

title: Justin_Gaethje
content:
Early life
Justin Ray Gaethje was born on November 14, 1988, in Tucson, Arizona and was raised in Safford, Arizona His mother, Carolina (née Espinoza), is of Mexican descent from Sonora, Mexico  [11] and his father, John Ray Gaethje, is of German descent [12] [13] His mother was a postmaster while his father was a copper miner, as were both of his grandfathers His paternal grandfather boxed while serving in the United States Army [13] [14] Gaethje's father Ray retired as a copper miner in September 2019, after 36 years working at the Morenci mine [15]


Wrestling career
Gaethje began wrestling at the age of four [17] He attended Safford High School, [18] where he was a four-time finalist and two-time state champion (AIA) [19] He still holds the seventh-most near falls (218) and the ninth-most team points scored (1057.5) in the history of the state as a wrestler [20] [21] Gaethje also played football and baseball in high school [22]


High-school
Gaethje began wrestling at the age of four [17] He attended Safford High School, [18] where he was a four-time finalist and two-time state champion (AIA) [19] He still holds the seventh-most near falls (218) and the ninth-most team points scored (1057.5) in the history of the state as a wrestler [20] [21] Gaethje also played football and baseball in high school [22]


Collegiate
Gaethje graduated from Safford High School with a 191–9 record [23] He initially applied to a small college in Arizona as he wanted to stay close to his family, but instead accepted an offer from the NCAA Division I program at the University of Northern Colorado [24] As a freshman, Gaethje had an 18–9 record, including a third-place finish at the Oregon Wrestling Classic In his sophomore season, he qualified for the 2009 NCAA Division I 157 lb Championship, where he posted a 0–2 record He finished the season with a 14–4 record and was named to the Western Wrestling All-Conference First Team [23]


Mixed martial arts career
Gaethje first came into contact with mixed martial arts (MMA) as a freshman at the University of Northern Colorado, when he wrestled Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) fighters such as Georges St-Pierre, Clay Guida and future opponent Donald Cerrone Afterward, he talked to his coaches about his intentions on trying out the new sport, to which he was told that he had to get his grades up in order to get an amateur bout [33] After improving his grades, Gaethje made his amateur debut during the pre-season of his sophomore year (08'-09') on August 2, 2008, where he scored a slam knockout on his opponent [34]

World Series of Fighting

UFC interim Lightweight Champion and further title contention

article:
**Justin Gaethje**

Justin Gaethje is an American mixed martial artist who currently competes in the lightweight division of the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC). He is a former champion in the World Series of Fighting (WSOF) and has also competed in the NCAA Division I.

**Early Life**

Justin Ray Gaethje was born on November 14, 1988, in Tucson, Arizona, and was raised in Safford, Arizona. His mother, Carolina (née Espinoza), is of Mexican descent from Sonora, Mexico, and his father, John Ray Gaethje, is of German descent. His mother was a postmaster, while his father was a copper miner, as were both of his grandfathers. Gaethje's father, Ray, retired as a copper miner in September 2019, after 36 years working at the Morenci mine.

**Wrestling Career**

Gaethje began wrestling at the age of four. He attended Safford High School, where he was a four-time finalist and two-time state champion (AIA). He still holds the seventh-most near falls (218) and the ninth-most team points scored (1057.5) in the history of the state as a wrestler. Gaethje also played football and baseball in high school.

**High School**

Gaethje attended Safford High School, where he excelled in wrestling. He was a four-time finalist and two-time state champion (AIA) and holds several school records. Gaethje's wrestling credentials are among the best in the state of Arizona.

**Collegiate**

Gaethje graduated from Safford High School with a 191–9 record. He initially applied to a small college in Arizona as he wanted to stay close to his family, but instead accepted an offer from the NCAA Division I program at the University of Northern Colorado. As a freshman, Gaethje had an 18–9 record, including a third-place finish at the Oregon Wrestling Classic. In his sophomore season, he qualified for the 2009 NCAA Division I 157 lb Championship, where he posted a 0–2 record. He finished the season with a 14–4 record and was named to the Western Wrestling All-Conference First Team.

**Mixed Martial Arts Career**

Gaethje first came into contact with mixed martial arts (MMA) as a freshman at the University of Northern Colorado, when he wrestled Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) fighters such as Georges St-Pierre, Clay Guida, and future opponent Donald Cerrone. Afterward, he talked to his coaches about his intentions on trying out the new sport, to which he was told that he had to get his grades up in order to get an amateur bout. After improving his grades, Gaethje made his amateur debut during the pre-season of his sophomore year (08'-09') on August 2, 2008, where he scored a slam knockout on his opponent.

**Early Career**

Gaethje's first professional MMA fight was in 2012, where he won against a Mexican fighter. He then moved to the United States and began competing in the WSOF, where he won his first title in 2014. Gaethje's success in the WSOF led to him signing with the UFC in 2017.

**World Series of Fighting**

Gaethje was signed by the World Series of Fighting on December 2, 2012. He made his debut on March 23, 2013, at WSOF 2 against Gesias Cavalcante, finishing the fight in the first round through TKO (doctor stoppage) after opening a cut above Cavalcante's left eye.

**Ultimate Fighting Championship**

On May 4, 2017, Gaethje announced he had vacated his WSOF title and signed with the Ultimate Fighting Championship. It was announced on May 12 that he would make his debut against the veteran Michael Johnson on July 7, at The Ultimate Fighter: Redemption Finale. Gaethje won the back-and-forth fight via TKO in the second round through a combination of punches and knees. The win earned Gaethje the Fight of the Night and Performance of the Night awards. Sherdog named this fight as the best fight of 2017, and round 2 of the fight as the best round of the year.

**UFC Interim Lightweight Champion and Further Title Contention**

On April 6, it was announced that Gaethje would step in on short notice to face Tony Ferguson for the interim UFC Lightweight Championship on April 18, at UFC 249. However, on April 9, UFC president Dana White announced that this event had been postponed, and the bout instead took place on May 9, 2020. Gaethje dominated the fight, stopping Ferguson via TKO in the fifth round, and thus ending Ferguson's personal best of 12 consecutive wins. He also continued his bonus award streak, earning the Fight of the Night and Performance of the Night awards. This made Gaethje the only fighter in UFC history to win at least one fight night bonus in each of his first seven appearances.

**Fighting Style**

As a two-time Arizona State high school champion and an NCAA Division I All-American, Gaethje has some of the best wrestling credentials in the UFC's lightweight division. Despite his elite wrestling pedigree, he rarely looks for takedowns, instead preferring an entertaining stand-up fighting style. He is well known for the knockout power in his punches and his debilitating leg kicks. When asked after his loss to Poirier in 2018 why he did not use his wrestling in the bout, Gaethje said, "I've been wrestling my whole life. I should've and could've took him down a couple of times, especially when I had him rocked just to steal a round or two. For some reason, my mind will not let me do it. I think I sold myself so hard on the fact that this is not wrestling. It gets you tired. If I'm going to get tired, I'd rather it be from fighting and not from wrestling."

**Personal Life**

Gaethje holds a bachelor's degree in Human Services from the University of Northern Colorado. He has stated his intention to do social work with at-risk youth. Gaethje's surname is of German origin due to his German-American father.

**Championships and Accomplishments**

* WSOF Interim Lightweight Championship (1 time)
* WSOF Lightweight Championship (1 time)
* UFC Interim Lightweight Championship (1 time)
* NCAA Division I All-American
* Two-time AIA (Arizona Interscholastic Association) State Wrestling Champion

**Mixed Martial Arts Record**

* Professional record: 23-3 (1 NC)
* Wins: 23
* Losses: 3
* Draws: 1

**NCAA Record**

* 191-9 record in high school wrestling

**Pay-per-view bouts**

* UFC 249: Gaethje vs. Ferguson (2020)

**See also**

* List of current UFC fighters

References

External links

* Justin Gaethje on Twitter
* Justin Gaethje on Instagram
