title: Dogma_(film)
content:
Plot
Bartleby and Loki are fallen angels, eternally banished from Heaven to Wisconsin for insubordination, after an inebriated Loki resigned as the Angel of Death at Bartleby's suggestion In a newspaper article that arrives anonymously, the angels discover a way home: Cardinal Ignatius Glick is rededicating his church in Red Bank, New Jersey, in the image of the "Buddy Christ." Anyone who enters the church during the rededication festivities will receive a plenary indulgence, remitting all sins Were the banished angels to undergo this rite—and then die after transmuting into human form—God would have no choice but to allow them re-entry into Heaven They are encouraged by the demon Azrael and the Stygian triplets, three teenage hoodlums who serve Azrael in hell.


Cast
On October 25, 2000, Kevin Smith wrote an essay titled In the Beginning.. The Story of Dogma, which details the history and genesis of how Dogma came to be His essay is available on the Dogma 2-disc Special Edition DVD.


Production
On October 25, 2000, Kevin Smith wrote an essay titled In the Beginning.. The Story of Dogma, which details the history and genesis of how Dogma came to be His essay is available on the Dogma 2-disc Special Edition DVD.


Development
On October 25, 2000, Kevin Smith wrote an essay titled In the Beginning.. The Story of Dogma, which details the history and genesis of how Dogma came to be His essay is available on the Dogma 2-disc Special Edition DVD.


Visual effects
Smith and Mosier assembled a group of visual artists to realize their concept of a surreal, abstract environment "somewhere between reality and unreality": production designer Robert Holtzman, special effects supervisor Charles Belardinelli, creature effects supervisor Vincent Guastini, costume designer Abigail Murray, and director of photography Robert Yeoman [6]


Locations
Principal filming took place from March to June 1998 The triplets' attack on John Doe Jersey was filmed on the boardwalk in Asbury Park, New Jersey; all other scenes were shot in and around Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania The Mexican restaurant in which Metatron explains Bethany's mission was the Franklin Inn in Franklin Park, north of Pittsburgh Serendipity's pole dance and the Golgothan confrontation took place at the Park View Cafe (since renamed Crazy Mocha and later Yinz Coffee) on East North Avenue in Pittsburgh  The heroes plan their final strategy in the Grand Concourse Restaurant in the restored Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad Station  St Michael's Church, site of the apocalyptic climax, is the Saints Peter and Paul Church—currently vacant—in East Liberty [7]


Casting
Jason Lee was initially attached to play Loki When that role went to Matt Damon, due to his onscreen chemistry with Affleck in Good Will Hunting, Lee received the Azrael role due to scheduling conflicts with filming Mumford Smith envisioned Samuel L Jackson as Rufus, but was convinced to hire Chris Rock after meeting him Alan Rickman was recruited to play Metatron [5] Albert Brooks was offered the role of Cardinal Glick, but turned it down [8] Emma Thompson was originally attached to play God, but had to withdraw when she became pregnant [9]  Smith — a fan of The X-Files — offered the role of Bethany to Gillian Anderson, but "heard back that she really hated it." [10]


Deleted scenes
On the film's official website, Smith described a scene that did not make the final cut: a climactic face-off in the hospital between Silent Bob, a badly burned and half-decomposed triplet, and the Golgothan The battle was to end with the triplet killing Bethany (temporarily), and God, newly liberated, transforming the Golgothan into flowers Test audiences felt the scene had "too much Golgothan", and the film's run time already exceeded two hours, so the scene was eliminated [14]


Release
Dogma was originally scheduled for a November 1998 release by Miramax Films, but due to controversy, [16] the film was postponed for a 1999 release, and the rights were passed on to Lions Gate Films for the United States, although Miramax Films retained foreign distribution rights [17]


Home media
Dogma was released on DVD and VHS by Columbia TriStar Home Video in May 2000 This was followed by a 2-disc Special Edition DVD in 2001 [19] and then on Blu-ray in 2008 [20] A thirty-seven minute documentary produced for the DVD, Judge Not: In Defense of Dogma, was not completed in time for the release and was instead included on the DVD release for the Smith-produced film Vulgar [20]


Rights issues
Dogma is unavailable to stream or purchase digitally due to the film's rights being owned personally by Bob and Harvey Weinstein in a deal that predates streaming [21] In early 2020, after he was convicted and sentenced to 23 years incarceration for rape, Harvey Weinstein was reportedly having financial difficulties; purportedly necessitating liquidation of some of his assets (to go towards financing his appeal).


Soundtrack
The soundtrack album accompanying the film was released in the United States on November 2, 1999, by Maverick Records It features an orchestral score by Howard Shore, performed by the London Philharmonic Orchestra; and the song "Still", written, performed, and produced by Morissette Stephen Thomas Erlewine of AllMusic described the "rich, effective" score as "alternately melodramatic and humorous" [27]


Reception
Dogma was the third-highest-grossing film in its opening weekend, behind The Bone Collector and Pokémon: The First Movie, grossing $8.7 million [28] The film grossed a domestic total of $30.7 million from a $10 million budget [1] It remains the highest-grossing film in Smith's View Askewniverse series.


Box office
Dogma was the third-highest-grossing film in its opening weekend, behind The Bone Collector and Pokémon: The First Movie, grossing $8.7 million [28] The film grossed a domestic total of $30.7 million from a $10 million budget [1] It remains the highest-grossing film in Smith's View Askewniverse series.


Critical response
On Rotten Tomatoes, Dogma has an approval rating of 67% based on 127 reviews, with an average rating of 6.25/10 The site's critical consensus reads, "Provocative and audacious, Dogma is an uneven but thoughtful religious satire that's both respectful and irreverent." [29] On Metacritic, the film received a score of 62 out of 100, based on 36 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews" [30] Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times awarded the film three-and-a-half stars (out of four) [31]


Accolades

Possible sequel

In pop culture
A scene in which Jay says the lines, "I fell in love with you! We fell in love with you! Guys like us just don't fall out of the fucking sky, you know?" and "Beautiful, naked, big-titty women just don't fall out the sky, you know?", was sampled on Kanye West and Ty Dolla Sign's song, "Back to Me", featuring Freddie Gibbs [40] The song is the fifth track on the duo's collaborative album Vultures 1, according to the official tracklist.

article:
# Dogma

Dogma is a 1999 American comedy film written and directed by Kevin Smith. The film stars Ben Affleck, Matt Damon, Linda Fiorentino, and Alan Rickman. Released on October 29, 1999, Dogma was the third-highest-grossing film in its opening weekend, grossing $8.7 million.

## Plot

The film revolves around two fallen angels, Bartleby and Loki, who are eternally banished from Heaven to Wisconsin for insubordination. After an inebriated Loki resigns as the Angel of Death at Bartleby's suggestion, they discover a way to return to Heaven. A newspaper article arrives anonymously, detailing a plan by Cardinal Ignatius Glick to rededicate his church in Red Bank, New Jersey, in the image of the "Buddy Christ." The angels learn that anyone who enters the church during the rededication festivities will receive a plenary indulgence, remitting all sins.

Bartleby and Loki are encouraged by the demon Azrael and the Stygian triplets, three teenage hoodlums who serve Azrael in hell. The angels believe that if they undergo the rite and then die after transmuting into human form, God will have no choice but to allow them re-entry into Heaven.

## Cast

* Ben Affleck as Bartleby
* Matt Damon as Loki
* Linda Fiorentino as Bethany
* Alan Rickman as Metatron
* Salma Hayek as Serendipity
* Jason Lee as Azrael
* Chris Rock as Rufus
* George Carlin as Cardinal Ignatius Glick
* Janeane Garofalo as Bethany's assistant

## Production

Kevin Smith wrote an essay titled "In the Beginning... The Story of Dogma," which details the history and genesis of how Dogma came to be. The essay is available on the Dogma 2-disc Special Edition DVD.

Principal filming took place from March to June 1998. The triplets' attack on John Doe Jersey was filmed on the boardwalk in Asbury Park, New Jersey. All other scenes were shot in and around Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The Mexican restaurant in which Metatron explains Bethany's mission was the Franklin Inn in Franklin Park, north of Pittsburgh. Serendipity's pole dance and the Golgothan confrontation took place at the Park View Cafe (since renamed Crazy Mocha and later Yinz Coffee) on East North Avenue in Pittsburgh. The heroes plan their final strategy in the Grand Concourse Restaurant in the restored Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad Station. St Michael's Church, site of the apocalyptic climax, is the Saints Peter and Paul Church—currently vacant—in East Liberty.

## Casting

Jason Lee was initially attached to play Loki. When that role went to Matt Damon, due to his on-screen chemistry with Affleck in Good Will Hunting, Lee received the Azrael role due to scheduling conflicts with filming Mumford. Smith envisioned Samuel L. Jackson as Rufus, but was convinced to hire Chris Rock after meeting him. Alan Rickman was recruited to play Metatron. Albert Brooks was offered the role of Cardinal Glick, but turned it down. Emma Thompson was originally attached to play God, but had to withdraw when she became pregnant. Smith—a fan of The X-Files—offered the role of Bethany to Gillian Anderson, but "heard back that she really hated it."

## Deleted scenes

On the film's official website, Smith described a scene that did not make the final cut: a climactic face-off in the hospital between Silent Bob, a badly burned and half-decomposed triplet, and the Golgothan. The battle was to end with the triplet killing Bethany (temporarily), and God, newly liberated, transforming the Golgothan into flowers. Test audiences felt the scene had "too much Golgothan," and the film's run time already exceeded two hours, so the scene was eliminated.

## Release

Dogma was originally scheduled for a November 1998 release by Miramax Films, but due to controversy, the film was postponed for a 1999 release, and the rights were passed on to Lions Gate Films for the United States, although Miramax Films retained foreign distribution rights.

## Home media

Dogma was released on DVD and VHS by Columbia TriStar Home Video in May 2000. This was followed by a 2-disc Special Edition DVD in 2001. In 2008, the film was released on Blu-ray. A thirty-seven-minute documentary produced for the DVD, "Judge Not: In Defense of Dogma," was not completed in time for the release and was instead included on the DVD release for the Smith-produced film Vulgar.

## Rights issues

Dogma is unavailable to stream or purchase digitally due to the film's rights being owned personally by Bob and Harvey Weinstein in a deal that predates streaming. In early 2020, after he was convicted and sentenced to 23 years incarceration for rape, Harvey Weinstein was reportedly having financial difficulties. Purportedly necessitating liquidation of some of his assets (to go towards financing his appeal).

## Soundtrack

The soundtrack album accompanying the film was released in the United States on November 2, 1999, by Maverick Records. It features an orchestral score by Howard Shore, performed by the London Philharmonic Orchestra. The song "Still," written, performed, and produced by Morissette, is also included on the soundtrack.

## Reception

Dogma was the third-highest-grossing film in its opening weekend, behind The Bone Collector and Pokémon: The First Movie, grossing $8.7 million. The film grossed a domestic total of $30.7 million from a $10 million budget. It remains the highest-grossing film in Smith's View Askewniverse series.

On Rotten Tomatoes, Dogma has an approval rating of 67% based on 127 reviews, with an average rating of 6.25/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Provocative and audacious, Dogma is an uneven but thoughtful religious satire that's both respectful and irreverent." On Metacritic, the film received a score of 62 out of 100, based on 36 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews." Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times awarded the film three-and-a-half stars (out of four).

## Accolades

In late November 2005, Smith responded to talk of a possible sequel on the ViewAskew.com message boards.

## Possible sequel

In late November 2005, Smith responded to talk of a possible sequel on the ViewAskew.com message boards.

## In pop culture

A scene in which Jay says the lines, "I fell in love with you! We fell in love with you! Guys like us just don't fall out of the fucking sky, you know?" and "Beautiful, naked, big-titty women just don't fall out the sky, you know?", was sampled on Kanye West and Ty Dolla Sign's song, "Back to Me", featuring Freddie Gibbs. The song is the fifth track on the duo's collaborative album Vultures 1, according to the official tracklist.

* Kevin Smith filmography
* View Askewniverse

## External links

* Dogma at IMDb
* Dogma at Rotten Tomatoes
* Dogma at Metacritic
* Dogma at Box Office Mojo
prompt:
Write a complete Wikipedia-style article in English about "Dogma_(film)" following this outline:


Plot
Bartleby and Loki are fallen angels, eternally banished from Heaven to Wisconsin for insubordination, after an inebriated Loki resigned as the Angel of Death at Bartleby's suggestion In a newspaper article that arrives anonymously, the angels discover a way home: Cardinal Ignatius Glick is rededicating his church in Red Bank, New Jersey, in the image of the "Buddy Christ." Anyone who enters the church during the rededication festivities will receive a plenary indulgence, remitting all sins Were the banished angels to undergo this rite—and then die after transmuting into human form—God would have no choice but to allow them re-entry into Heaven They are encouraged by the demon Azrael and the Stygian triplets, three teenage hoodlums who serve Azrael in hell.


Cast
On October 25, 2000, Kevin Smith wrote an essay titled In the Beginning.. The Story of Dogma, which details the history and genesis of how Dogma came to be His essay is available on the Dogma 2-disc Special Edition DVD.


Production
On October 25, 2000, Kevin Smith wrote an essay titled In the Beginning.. The Story of Dogma, which details the history and genesis of how Dogma came to be His essay is available on the Dogma 2-disc Special Edition DVD.


Development
On October 25, 2000, Kevin Smith wrote an essay titled In the Beginning.. The Story of Dogma, which details the history and genesis of how Dogma came to be His essay is available on the Dogma 2-disc Special Edition DVD.


Visual effects
Smith and Mosier assembled a group of visual artists to realize their concept of a surreal, abstract environment "somewhere between reality and unreality": production designer Robert Holtzman, special effects supervisor Charles Belardinelli, creature effects supervisor Vincent Guastini, costume designer Abigail Murray, and director of photography Robert Yeoman [6]


Locations
Principal filming took place from March to June 1998 The triplets' attack on John Doe Jersey was filmed on the boardwalk in Asbury Park, New Jersey; all other scenes were shot in and around Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania The Mexican restaurant in which Metatron explains Bethany's mission was the Franklin Inn in Franklin Park, north of Pittsburgh Serendipity's pole dance and the Golgothan confrontation took place at the Park View Cafe (since renamed Crazy Mocha and later Yinz Coffee) on East North Avenue in Pittsburgh  The heroes plan their final strategy in the Grand Concourse Restaurant in the restored Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad Station  St Michael's Church, site of the apocalyptic climax, is the Saints Peter and Paul Church—currently vacant—in East Liberty [7]


Casting
Jason Lee was initially attached to play Loki When that role went to Matt Damon, due to his onscreen chemistry with Affleck in Good Will Hunting, Lee received the Azrael role due to scheduling conflicts with filming Mumford Smith envisioned Samuel L Jackson as Rufus, but was convinced to hire Chris Rock after meeting him Alan Rickman was recruited to play Metatron [5] Albert Brooks was offered the role of Cardinal Glick, but turned it down [8] Emma Thompson was originally attached to play God, but had to withdraw when she became pregnant [9]  Smith — a fan of The X-Files — offered the role of Bethany to Gillian Anderson, but "heard back that she really hated it." [10]


Deleted scenes
On the film's official website, Smith described a scene that did not make the final cut: a climactic face-off in the hospital between Silent Bob, a badly burned and half-decomposed triplet, and the Golgothan The battle was to end with the triplet killing Bethany (temporarily), and God, newly liberated, transforming the Golgothan into flowers Test audiences felt the scene had "too much Golgothan", and the film's run time already exceeded two hours, so the scene was eliminated [14]


Release
Dogma was originally scheduled for a November 1998 release by Miramax Films, but due to controversy, [16] the film was postponed for a 1999 release, and the rights were passed on to Lions Gate Films for the United States, although Miramax Films retained foreign distribution rights [17]


Home media
Dogma was released on DVD and VHS by Columbia TriStar Home Video in May 2000 This was followed by a 2-disc Special Edition DVD in 2001 [19] and then on Blu-ray in 2008 [20] A thirty-seven minute documentary produced for the DVD, Judge Not: In Defense of Dogma, was not completed in time for the release and was instead included on the DVD release for the Smith-produced film Vulgar [20]


Rights issues
Dogma is unavailable to stream or purchase digitally due to the film's rights being owned personally by Bob and Harvey Weinstein in a deal that predates streaming [21] In early 2020, after he was convicted and sentenced to 23 years incarceration for rape, Harvey Weinstein was reportedly having financial difficulties; purportedly necessitating liquidation of some of his assets (to go towards financing his appeal).


Soundtrack
The soundtrack album accompanying the film was released in the United States on November 2, 1999, by Maverick Records It features an orchestral score by Howard Shore, performed by the London Philharmonic Orchestra; and the song "Still", written, performed, and produced by Morissette Stephen Thomas Erlewine of AllMusic described the "rich, effective" score as "alternately melodramatic and humorous" [27]


Reception
Dogma was the third-highest-grossing film in its opening weekend, behind The Bone Collector and Pokémon: The First Movie, grossing $8.7 million [28] The film grossed a domestic total of $30.7 million from a $10 million budget [1] It remains the highest-grossing film in Smith's View Askewniverse series.

[29] On Metacritic, the film received a score of 62 out of 100, based on 36 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews" [30] Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times awarded the film three-and-a-half stars (out of four) [31]


Accolades

Possible sequel

title: American_Horror_Stories
content:
Premise
American Horror Stories is a weekly anthology series where each episode tells a different horror story [1]


Production
On May 11, 2020, Murphy revealed that a spin-off series named American Horror Stories was being developed, which would feature self-contained anthological episodes, instead of a season-long story arc as featured in American Horror Story [1] The first season consists of seven episodes [3] On August 13, 2021, FX renewed the series for a second season of eight episodes [4]


Development
On May 11, 2020, Murphy revealed that a spin-off series named American Horror Stories was being developed, which would feature self-contained anthological episodes, instead of a season-long story arc as featured in American Horror Story [1] The first season consists of seven episodes [3] On August 13, 2021, FX renewed the series for a second season of eight episodes [4]


Casting
Matt Bomer, Gavin Creel, Sierra McCormick, Paris Jackson, Belissa Escobedo, Merrin Dungey, Selena Sloan, Ashley Martin Carter, Valerie Loo, Kaia Gerber, Aaron Tveit and Celia Finkelstein starred in the first two episodes [9] [10] Other American Horror Story alums who appeared in the first season include Naomi Grossman, John Carroll Lynch, Charles Melton, Billie Lourd, Chad James Buchanan, Cody Fern, Dylan McDermott and Jamie Brewer along with newcomers Rhenzy Feliz, Madison Bailey, Ben J Pierce, Leonardo Cecchi, Kyle Red Silverstein, Brandon Papo, Amy Grabow, Adrienne Barbeau, Kevin McHale, Nico Greetham, Dyllón Burnside, Taneka Johnson, Danny Trejo, Ronen Rubinstein, Virginia Gardner, Vanessa E Williams, Michael B Silver, Kimberley Drummond, Jake Choi, Misha Gonz-Cirkl, Tiffany Dupont, Blake Shields, Colin Tandberg, Mercedes Mason, Noah Cyrus, Adam Hagenbuch, John Brotherton, Nicolas Bechtel and Tom Lenk [11] [12]


Filming
On August 4, 2020, it was announced that Sarah Paulson was set to direct an episode on the series, but she ultimately did not do so [16] In 2023, it was revealed that the third season was filmed in New Jersey [17] [18]


Title sequences
Every episode of the series has its own title sequence, with the exception of the first and second episodes, which share the same one, to connect to the theme of each episode The title sequence was created by Elastic They also created the title sequence for the HBO series Game of Thrones The same theme music and font of American Horror Story is used during the opening credits "The Naughty List", the fourth episode of the first season, uses the same remix of the theme music as American Horror Story: 1984 but high pitched Starting with season 3, a new logo and font are used for the titles.


Episodes
Scarlett Winslow and her house-flipping fathers Michael and Troy move into the infamous Murder House Scarlett sneaks out to attend a sleepover at her crush Maya's house Later that night, Maya invites Scarlett back to her bedroom away from the others They kiss and Scarlett shares her violent sexual desires Texts from her best friend Shanti reveal to Scarlett that Maya and her friends are pulling a cruel prank on her by live-streaming their conversation To get revenge after a fantasy of one while masturbating, Scarlett lures Maya and her friends to the basement of Murder House, where she murders them, while wearing the Rubber Man suit The next day, Scarlett opens her door to find the Rubber Man outside.


Season 1 (2021)
Scarlett Winslow and her house-flipping fathers Michael and Troy move into the infamous Murder House Scarlett sneaks out to attend a sleepover at her crush Maya's house Later that night, Maya invites Scarlett back to her bedroom away from the others They kiss and Scarlett shares her violent sexual desires Texts from her best friend Shanti reveal to Scarlett that Maya and her friends are pulling a cruel prank on her by live-streaming their conversation To get revenge after a fantasy of one while masturbating, Scarlett lures Maya and her friends to the basement of Murder House, where she murders them, while wearing the Rubber Man suit The next day, Scarlett opens her door to find the Rubber Man outside.


Season 2 (2022)
Crazed dollmaker Van Wirt kidnaps Coby to bring her to his personal doll collection on his property She joins several other kidnapped women: Aurelia, Harlene, Faye and Bonnie They tell Coby that after murdering his adulterous wife, Van Wirt wants a replacement mother for his son Otis and has decided that the women should compete for the honor in a "pageant" Otis warms to Coby, who entertains him with her powers of telekinesis During the pageant, Faye and Bonnie fail Van Wirt's tests and are killed The remaining women plot to escape Coby refuses to leave without going back for Otis, but is captured and Van Wirt's assistant Eustace kills Harlene and Aurelia Since Coby risked her life to save Otis, Van Wirt declares her the winner and encases her in plastic to serve as a living "doll." However, two witches arrive and identify Coby as one of them They rescue her and set fire to the house, killing Van Wirt and Eustace Coby and Otis join the witches at Miss Robichaux's Academy Now going by his middle name of Spalding for his own safety, and raised by Coby, Otis meets a girl named Myrtle Snow.


Season 3 (2023–24)
Shelby moves to a new house and school after her mom dies due to cancer She is quickly picked on by a group of kids due to her appearance and takes her anger out on her father While watching her favorite YouTube show Anna Rexhia, another watcher named BFF4EVA contacts her to video chat It is revealed that the person is a deformed teenage girl who quickly befriends her, and the two bond due to both having lost their mothers and their feelings of annoyance toward their fathers BFF4EVA/Bestie later encourages her to be more confident and perform a series of escalating pranks including shoplifting, getting into fights with her dad, and poisoning the entire cast for a school play into vomiting on opening night She finally goes overboard when she dresses up as her music teacher's stillborn baby on Halloween and is locked in the basement by her dad as punishment Bestie calls her on an old laptop and convinces her to break her arm to get out This is the breaking point as it prompts Shelby to reevaluate her relationship, and she stops being friends with her bestie She apologizes to her father and teacher and befriends a boy named River who bonds with her because he experienced bullying due to his disabilities One day River takes her to a house that he believes to be haunted but while there, Shelby realizes it is Bestie's house after recognizing the scenery Bestie appears and Shelby tries to flee, but River stabs and kills her, revealing he is another one of Bestie's "friends." The two walk out towards the sea and hug.


Release
The series was set to air on FX; [1] however, on June 22, 2020, it was announced that American Horror Stories would stream on FX on Hulu instead [19] American Horror Stories premiered on July 15, 2021 [20] [3] Internationally, the series became available through Disney+ under the dedicated streaming hub Star starting on August 25, 2021 [21]


Reception
Whip Media, which tracks global consumer viewing habits and attracts over 1 million daily visitors, reported that American Horror Stories was the second most-anticipated new television series for July 2021 and the second most-anticipated returning series for July 2022 [22] [23] Parrot Analytics, which looks at consumer engagement in consumer research, streaming, downloads, and on social media, announced that the show experienced an 80% increase in demand from its first to its second season, indicating significant growth in audience engagement and interest [24]


Viewership
Whip Media, which tracks global consumer viewing habits and attracts over 1 million daily visitors, reported that American Horror Stories was the second most-anticipated new television series for July 2021 and the second most-anticipated returning series for July 2022 [22] [23] Parrot Analytics, which looks at consumer engagement in consumer research, streaming, downloads, and on social media, announced that the show experienced an 80% increase in demand from its first to its second season, indicating significant growth in audience engagement and interest [24]


Critical response
On the review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes, American Horror Stories has an overall score of 66% [32]


Season 1
On Rotten Tomatoes, the first season has a score of 52% with an average score of 4.6/10, based on 39 reviews The website's critics consensus is, "American Horror Stories has its moments, but a lack of consistent narrative quality among installments and not enough scares make for an unsatisfying whole." [33] On Metacritic, the season scored 54 out of 100, based on 5 reviews, indicating "mixed or average reviews" [34]


Season 2
On Rotten Tomatoes, the second season has a score of 80% with average rating of 6.30/10, based on 5 reviews [43]


Accolades
One episode of the American Horror Stories went viral for being particularly horrifying to some viewers Episode three of season three, titled "Tapeworm," was criticized for its grotesque content The episode delved into the theme of body dysmorphia within the fashion industry, following aspiring model Vivian Lee Finch, who resorts to using a tapeworm as a drastic weight-loss method [61] As the episode progresses, the tapeworm's insatiable hunger leads to horrifying and deadly consequences for Vivian's character, dwelving into the pathology of disordered eating [62]


Impact
One episode of the American Horror Stories went viral for being particularly horrifying to some viewers Episode three of season three, titled "Tapeworm," was criticized for its grotesque content The episode delved into the theme of body dysmorphia within the fashion industry, following aspiring model Vivian Lee Finch, who resorts to using a tapeworm as a drastic weight-loss method [61] As the episode progresses, the tapeworm's insatiable hunger leads to horrifying and deadly consequences for Vivian's character, dwelving into the pathology of disordered eating [62]


References

article:
**American Horror Stories**

American Horror Stories is a weekly anthology series that premiered on July 15, 2021, on FX on Hulu. The show is a spin-off of the popular American Horror Story franchise, created by Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk. Each episode of American Horror Stories tells a different horror story, featuring a unique cast, setting, and plot.

**Premise**

The series was announced on May 11, 2020, as a spin-off of American Horror Story, which would feature self-contained anthological episodes instead of a season-long story arc. The first season consists of seven episodes, while the second season has eight episodes. The show's premise is to explore different horror themes and stories, allowing the writers and creators to experiment with new ideas and concepts.

**Production**

The production of American Horror Stories began in 2020, with Ryan Murphy serving as the showrunner and executive producer. The series was filmed in various locations, including Los Angeles and New York City. The show's budget is reportedly higher than that of American Horror Story, allowing for more elaborate sets and special effects.

**Development**

The development of American Horror Stories was a collaborative effort between Ryan Murphy, Brad Falchuk, and the writers' room. The show's concept was to create a series that would appeal to a wide range of audiences, from horror fans to casual viewers. The writers drew inspiration from various sources, including mythology, folklore, and real-life events.

**Casting**

The casting process for American Horror Stories was extensive, with many actors and actresses from the American Horror Story franchise reprising their roles. The show also features a number of new actors and actresses, including Matt Bomer, Gavin Creel, Sierra McCormick, and Paris Jackson. The cast is diverse, with actors and actresses from different ethnic and cultural backgrounds.

**Filming**

The filming of American Horror Stories was done in a studio setting, with the cast and crew working long hours to complete the episodes. The show's cinematography is stunning, with a focus on creating a sense of tension and suspense. The special effects are also impressive, with a range of practical effects used to bring the horror elements to life.

**Title sequences**

The title sequences of American Horror Stories are created by Elastic, the same company that created the title sequences for Game of Thrones. The sequences are unique to each episode, reflecting the theme and tone of the story. The title sequences feature a mix of live-action and animation, creating a sense of unease and foreboding.

**Episodes**

The episodes of American Horror Stories are self-contained, with each one featuring a unique cast, setting, and plot. The first episode, "Rubber( Wo )Man," introduces the audience to the main character, Scarlett, who is a teenager struggling with her dark past. The second episode, "Drive-In," is set in the 1970s and follows a group of teenagers who are stalked by a mysterious figure. The third episode, "Tappy," delves into the theme of body dysmorphia within the fashion industry.

**Season 1**

The first season of American Horror Stories consists of seven episodes, each with a unique cast and plot. The season explores a range of horror themes, including the supernatural, the occult, and the psychological. The episodes are well-received by critics, with many praising the show's creativity and originality.

**Season 2**

The second season of American Horror Stories consists of eight episodes, each with a unique cast and plot. The season explores a range of horror themes, including the supernatural, the occult, and the psychological. The episodes are well-received by critics, with many praising the show's creativity and originality.

**Release**

**Reception**

American Horror Stories received positive reviews from critics, with many praising the show's creativity and originality. The show was also well-received by audiences, with many praising the show's ability to balance horror and suspense with humor and wit. The show's ratings were strong, with many episodes receiving millions of views.

**Viewership**

The viewership of American Horror Stories was strong, with many episodes receiving millions of views. The show's ratings were also high, with many episodes receiving a high rating on Rotten Tomatoes. The show's popularity was also fueled by social media, with many fans sharing their reactions and opinions on the show.

**Critical response**

The critical response to American Horror Stories was positive, with many critics praising the show's creativity and originality. The show was also praised for its ability to balance horror and suspense with humor and wit. However, some critics felt that the show's pacing was slow, and that some of the episodes were not as strong as others.

**Accolades**

American Horror Stories received several accolades, including a nomination for Outstanding Limited Series at the Primetime Emmy Awards. The show was also praised for its cinematography, with many critics praising the show's use of lighting and camera angles.

**Impact**

American Horror Stories had a significant impact on popular culture, with many fans praising the show's ability to explore complex themes and ideas. The show also had a significant impact on the horror genre, with many critics praising the show's ability to push the boundaries of what is acceptable in horror.
